facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 443 of 1959 filed in Supreme Court.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeal No. 443 of 1959. Appeal from the judgment and decree dated April 27, 1956, of the Patna High Court in L. P. A. No. 13 of 1954.

facts.text: Appeal from judgment and decree dated April 27, 1956, of Patna High Court in L.P.A. No. 13 of 1954.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal from the judgment and decree dated April 27, 1956, of the Patna High Court in L. P. A. No. 13 of 1954. K. Jha and B. P. Jha, for the appellants.

facts.text: Suit for declaration and delivery of possession of 12 bighas, 16 kathas, 4 dhurs of land in Mauza Chhatahara, District of Santhal Parganas.

anchor.surface_text: This is the main question raised in this appeal arising out of a suit for declaration and delivery of possession of 12 bighas, 16 kathas, 4 dhurs of land in Mauza, Chhatahara in the District of Santhal Parganas.

facts.text: Plaintiffs and four defendants (2nd party) are successors in interest of Santokhi Jha who became owner of entire raiyati interest in these lands many years ago.

anchor.surface_text: The plaintiffs and the four defendants, described in the plaint as defendants 2nd party, are the successors in interest of one Santokhi Jha who became owner of the entire raiyati interest in these lands many years ago.

facts.text: Santokhi Jha purchased by registered deed the entire interest of the Lakhirajdar under whom he was the raiyat, some time after becoming raiyat.

anchor.surface_text: Some time after he became a raiyat of this land, Santokhi purchased by a registered deed the entire interest of the Lakhirajdar under whom he was the raiyat.

facts.text: On May 15, 1935, lands sold by 2nd party defendants and plaintiffs 1 to 6 to present appellants.

anchor.surface_text: On May 15, 1935, these lands were sold by the 2nd party defendants and others including the plaintiffs 1 to 6, to the present appellants.

facts.text: Plaintiffs claimed no interest passed to vendees because raiyati character existed and inalienable under Regulation III of 1872.

anchor.surface_text: The plaintiffs case is that numberinterest passed to the vendees by that sale deed, because the raiyati character of the land was existing on the date of transfer and this was inalienable under the provisions of Regulation III of 1872.

facts.text: Plaintiffs pleaded 1935 transfer was fraudulent, collusive, no legal necessity.

anchor.surface_text: It was further pleaded that this transfer of 1935 was fraudulent and companylusive and that there was numberlegal neces- sity for the transfer.

facts.text: Defendants first party denied fraud or collusion, pleaded legal necessity for antecedent debts, binding on plaintiffs.

anchor.surface_text: The defendants first party denied the allegations of fraud or companylusion and further pleaded that the transfer was made for legal necessity for paying antecedent debts of the family and they are therefore binding on the plaintiffs.

facts.text: Defendants pleaded lands were Bakasht lands of Malik on sale date, no bar under Regulation III of 1872.

anchor.surface_text: They also pleaded that the lands in the suit were number, on the date of the sale, raiyati but Bakasht lands of the Malik and so there was numberbar to the sale of these lands under the provisions of Regulation III of 1872.

facts.text: Subordinate Judge Dumka held sale justified by legal necessity, not fraudulent or collusive, binding on plaintiffs, land lost raiyati character, dismissed suit.

anchor.surface_text: The Subordinate Judge, Dumka, who tried the suit held that the sale was justified by legal necessity and that it was number fraudulent or companylusive. He further held that while the plaintiffs were number estopped from challenging the sale deed it was binding on them.

facts.text: District Judge Santhal Parganas agreed with Trial Court, dismissed appeal.

anchor.surface_text: On appeal by the plaintiffs the District judge, Santhal Parganas, agreed with the findings of the Trial Court and held that the suit had been rightly dismissed.

facts.text: Patna High Court (Banerjee J) allowed plaintiffs' appeal, held raiyati interest continued, no merger, sale void re raiyati interest.

anchor.surface_text: The learned judge  Banerjee, J.  who heard the appeal, was of opinion that there was numberconflict between the several entries in the record of rights the first of which showed the lands as held by Santokhi as the raiyat while the later settlement records showed lands as Bakasht Malik and that in law the raiyati interest companytinued even after the raiyat acquired the superior landlords interest.

facts.text: Letters Patent Appeal by defendants 1st party unsuccessful in Patna High Court.

anchor.surface_text: The Letters Patent Appeal by the defendants 1st party from this decision was unsuccessful the learned judges who heard the appeal being of opinion, in agreement with Mr. justice Banerjee, that the raiyati interest recorded in the earlier settlement companytinued inspite of the entry Bakasht Malik in the subsequent Settlements

facts.text: High Court gave certificate under s.110 CPC and Art 135 Constitution for appeal to Supreme Court.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court, however, gave a certificate that as regards the value and nature of the case it fulfilled the requirements of s. 110 of the Code of Civil Procedure read with Article 135 of the Constitution of India and was a fit case for appeal to this Court.

facts.text: Santokhi objected in Settlement Objection Case No. 41 of 1909, stated purchased Zamindari interest three years ago, wanted land as Bakasht Malik.

anchor.surface_text: In their attempt to show that Santokhi decided to treat raiyati interest as merged in the Lakhirajdar interest the appellants relied on Ex. I--a certified companyy of the order-sheet in Settlement Objection Case No. 41 of 1909. The objection was made by Santokhi in respect of the entry in the record of rights of the land number in dispute.

facts.text: Settlement Officer approved entry of land as Bakasht Malik in 1909.

anchor.surface_text: The Settlement Officer approved of the proposal and the record was companyrected accordingly by entering Bakasht Malik against this land.

issues.text: If a raiyat of lands in the District of Santhal Parganas acquires the entire superior landlords interest, does his raiyati interest cease to exist or does he continue to be a raiyat in addition to becoming a superior landlord?

anchor.surface_text: If a raiyat of lands in the District of Santhal Parganas acquires the entire superior landlords interest, does his raiyati interest cease to exist or does he continue to be a raiyat in addition to becoming a superior landlord ?

issues.text: Was there an automatic merger of the raiyati interest in the larger interest upon acquisition of the superior landlord's interest?

anchor.surface_text: the language of the law of merger at English common law. Blackstone in his Commentaries on the Laws of England, Vol. The first argument is indeed the language of the law of merger at English common law.

issues.text: Did Santokhi have the option to merge the raiyati interest and did he exercise that option by intention?

anchor.surface_text: First, he argues that as a matter of law, there was an automatic merger of the raiyati interest in the larger interest, the Lakhirajdars interest. Secondly, it is argued that at least Santokhi had the option to merge the raiyati interest in the Lakbirajdars interest, and he exercised that option.

issues.text: Does the doctrine of merger apply to raiyati holders in the Santhal Parganas?

anchor.surface_text: We are inclined to hold, as at present advised, that the doctrine of merger does not apply to the case of raiyati holders in the Santhal Parganas but we do not wish to express a final opinion on this point in the present case.
